class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Open access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005"><span>The new types of 2D <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-carbide" title="Learn more about transition metal carbide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal carbide</a> and </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nitride" title="Learn more about nitride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nitride</a> electrode materials with high stability and capacity are needed.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Exhibits ultra-low energy barriers of 0.1 and 0.01&nbsp;eV for Li and Na, respectively.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Demonstrate excellent cycle stability, restoring its initial state within a mere 2.5 picoseconds.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">â€¢</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Exhibits storage capacity of 379.88 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for both Li and Na, respectively.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">We present first-principles insights into the electrical and electrochemical properties of Cu<sub>2</sub>N, a newly synthesized two-dimensional material that features a planar, checkerboard lattice structure [Hu et al., Nano Lett. 2023, 23 (12), 5610â€“5616]. We evaluate the suitability of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N as an anode material for Li and Na-ion batteries by examining its storage capacity, diffusion barrier, open-circuit voltage (OCV), volume expansion, and the impact of defects on its electrochemical performance. The monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N demonstrates a storage capacity of 379.88 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for both Li and Na, comparable to that of commercial graphite for Li (372 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and significantly higher for Na (less than 35â€‰mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). The migration barriers for Li and Na are found to be 0.1&nbsp;eV and 0.01&nbsp;eV, respectively, substantially lower than those theoretically reported for commercial anodes TiO<sub>2</sub> (0.4â€“1.0&nbsp;eV) and graphite (âˆ¼0.4&nbsp;eV), which imply that monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N demonstrates excellent charge/discharge capabilities. Moreover, the volume growth of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N is 4.14&nbsp;% with maximal Li adsorption, which is 2.4 times less than graphite. The analysis of vacancy defects reveals a significant enhancement in the binding energies of Li and Na atoms, accompanied by minimal changes in diffusion barriers. Since monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N has already been successfully synthesized, these findings would pave the way for large-scale experimental fabrication of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N as a battery anode.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0045"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-ga1.jpg" height="192" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (195KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (195KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S016943322400103X"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0169433224002101"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Checkerboard lattice</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Metal-ion batteries</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Anode material</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>High stability</span></div><div id="k0030" class="keyword"><span>Ultra-low diffusion barrier</span></div><div id="k0035" class="keyword"><span>Density functional theory calculations</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span><span>In recent years, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/renewable-energy" title="Learn more about renewable energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energy</a> sources have gained significant prominence as a sustainable solution to the world's growing energy demands and the need to mitigate climate change. Solar and </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/windpower-utilization" title="Learn more about wind energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wind energy</a>, in particular, have witnessed rapid advancements and widespread adoption. However, the intermittent nature of these energy sources necessitates efficient and reliable energy storage solutions, making batteries a crucial component of the renewable energy landscape </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a><span><span>. Besides, the rapid growth of portable electronic devices and electric vehicles has spurred intense research efforts to enhance energy storage technologies, including lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Central to these efforts is the exploration of novel <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> that can offer higher </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy densities from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy densities</a>, faster charge/discharge rates, and improved cycling stability. Graphite, though a conventional anode material in LIBs for decades, offers a limited theoretical specific capacity of 372 mAh.g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which has fostered the search for alternatives<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>. In this context, the emergence of two-dimensional (2D) materials has positioned them as potential contenders for anode applications in both LIBs and SIBs<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>. Their remarkable properties, characterized by high surface area, exceptional electronic conductivity, and distinctive structural characteristics, have fueled extensive interest in their potential as anode materials<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>Graphene, acclaimed for its extraordinary <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> and mechanical robustness</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a><span>, presents a compelling choice for anodes, where rapid <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a> is essential for high-rate charge/discharge processes. Additionally, graphene-based anodes have demonstrated superior specific capacities and cycling stability in comparison to graphite, attributed to their capacity to accommodate a greater quantity of Li/Na-ions</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a><span>. In parallel, <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-oxide" title="Learn more about transition metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal oxides</a> (TMOs)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a><span><span>, <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-carbide" title="Learn more about transition metal carbides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal carbides</a> (TMCs) and </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/nitride-compound" title="Learn more about nitrides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nitrides</a> (TMNs), also known as (MXenes)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, hexagonal transition metal borides (MBenes)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a><span>, and <a href="/topics/materials-science/transition-metal-dichalcogenide" title="Learn more about transition metal dichalcogenides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metal dichalcogenides</a> (TMDs)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, have been widely studied as electrode materials for Li and Na-ion batteries. Additionally, boron-based 2D materials have also emerged as a promising class of anode material for metal-ion batteries<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. These 2D materials offer intriguing possibilities for Li/Na anodes due to their layered structures accompanied by substantial specific capacities, metallic conductivity (or narrow bandgap semiconducting characteristics), and good cycling stability. Among all those possible candidates, MXenes have received the most attention as promising anode materials<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">MXenes, which were first synthesized by Naguib et al.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a> in 2011, are characterized by the chemical formula M<sub>n+1</sub>X<sub>n</sub><span>, where M is an early transition metal, X is carbon and/or nitrogen, and n is the thickness (n&nbsp;=&nbsp;1, 2, 3). To date, over a hundred <a href="/topics/materials-science/mxene" title="Learn more about MXene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">MXene</a> variants have been proposed theoretically, of which approximately 30 have been experimentally synthesized</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>. Recent theoretical studies demonstrate that MXenes (such as Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>, Ti<sub>2</sub>C, Nb<sub>2</sub>C, V<sub>2</sub>C, etc.) are excellent anodes for Li and Na-ion batteries because they have low diffusion barriers and a comparatively high storage capacity<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. However, the structure of MXenes is not stable in oxygen and water environments, and their basal faces are frequently terminated with F, O, or OH surface groups<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. Such terminations significantly reduce their storage capacity while simultaneously increasing the energy barrier for cation migration<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>. Therefore, it is important for future Li and Na battery advancements to explore new types of 2D TMCs/TMNs electrode materials that offer both high capacity and stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">There has been some theoretical work on the structural prediction of new type of 2D TMCs/TMNs and their application to LIBs/SIBs<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, but there is still a large gap between theoretical proposals and real-world implementation. Bridging this gap requires the synthesis of TMCs/TMNs with new and more stable structural configurations and a thorough exploration of their potential as anode materials for LIBs/SIBs. In this context, Hu and co-workers<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a> have recently synthesized a new 2D TMN, Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N, with a checkerboard lattice configuration via <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-beam-epitaxy" title="Learn more about molecular beam epitaxy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molecular beam epitaxy</a> on Cu(1</span>&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) and Cu(1&nbsp;1&nbsp;<span>1) substrates, and it demonstrates outstanding stability in air and <a href="/topics/materials-science/organic-solvents" title="Learn more about organic solvents from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic solvents</a>. These characteristics show its potential as a promising anode material for metal-ion batteries.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">Motivated by the remarkable stability and perfect planar checkerboard lattice structure of Cu<sub>2</sub>N, in this study, we investigate its potential as an anode material for LIBS and SIBs. We begin our investigation with a thorough examination of the adsorption behavior of Li/Na, with a particular emphasis on adsorption energies, binding distance, charge transfer, and charge density differences. The monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N shows great promise as an anode material in terms of its ultralow diffusion barrier, high electrical conductivity owing to its metallic nature, minimal volume expansion, and appreciable adsorption energies. We also examine the effect of Cu and N <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a><span> on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of Cu</span></span><sub>2</sub><span>N, as <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> are almost inevitable during material synthesis. Our study demonstrated that vacancy defects in monolayer Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N significantly enhance Li/Na binding and also lower the Li diffusion barrier in the case of Cu vacancies. These results highlight the promise of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N as anodes for battery applications.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Computational details</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span>The Vienna <a href="/topics/materials-science/ab-initio-simulation" title="Learn more about ab initio simulation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ab initio simulation</a> package (VASP)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span> was used to perform all the density-functional theory calculations by employing the projector-augmented wave method. The exchangeâ€“correlation functional was modeled using the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/generalized-gradient-approximation" title="Learn more about generalized gradient approximation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">generalized gradient approximation</a> (GGA)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a> scheme developed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE). The empirical correction approach suggested by Grimme (DFT&nbsp;+&nbsp;D3)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a> was used to implement the van der Waals interactions. The kinetic energy cutoff of 500&nbsp;eV was set for the plane wave basis expansion. A 15&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;15&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 and 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 Monkhorst-Pack k-grid<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a><span> was adapted for the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/brillouin-zone" title="Learn more about Brillouin zone from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Brillouin zone</a> integration of the unit cell and the 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 supercell of monolayer Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N. The energy and force convergence thresholds were established at 10<sup>âˆ’6</sup> eV and 0.05&nbsp;eV/Ã…, respectively. To prevent spurious interactions caused by periodic images, a 20&nbsp;Ã… vacuum was added to the <em>z</em>-axis. The Bader charge<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a> method was used to calculate the amount of charge transfer between monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N and adsorbates (Li/Na). The adsorption energies (<em>E<sub>ad</sub></em>) for the adsorbates on Cu<sub>2</sub>N surface are determined according to the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="e0005" class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-17-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>u</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.341ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2730.3 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g is="true">N</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-17"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mi <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-18-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BC;</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi width="6.858ex" height="2.202ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 2952.9 947.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.043ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BC"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(603,-187)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4C"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69" x="681" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(892,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1246,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1875,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">Î¼</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Li</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-18"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">Î¼</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Li</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span> is the energy of a single adsorbate atom in its bulk state. The climbing-image nudged elastic band method (CI-NEB)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a> was used to compute the diffusion barriers and minimum energy paths (MEP) for adsorbate atoms on the Cu<sub>2</sub>N surface. NEB calculations were performed on seven intermediate images between the initial and final states, which were then verified by optimizing the structures until the tangential forces on each image reached values less than 0.01&nbsp;eV/Ã….</div></section><section id="s0015"><h2 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">The monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N crystallizes in a tetragonal configuration with space group P4/mmm (No. 123) as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (a) and (b). The primitive unit cell of Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N contains two Cu and one N atom, which occupy the 2f and 1a Wyckoff positions, respectively. The optimized <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> of ML Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N are <em>a</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>b</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;3.65&nbsp;Ã…, with cell angles Î±&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>Î²</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>Î³</em><span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;90Â°. Each Cu atom forms <a href="/topics/materials-science/covalent-bond" title="Learn more about covalent bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">covalent bonds</a> with two adjacent N atoms and four Cu atoms with a bond length of 1.83&nbsp;Ã… and 2.58&nbsp;Ã…, respectively. The corresponding BZ with high-symmetry points is shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>c. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/electronic-band-structure" title="Learn more about electronic band structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic band structure</a>, along with the projected density of states (PDOS) are depicted in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(d). It is clear that the system is highly metallic, which suggests its exceptional electronic conductivity, rendering it a promising choice for a metal-ion battery anode. Further, the PDOS shows that the low-energy states near the Fermi level are mainly composed of Cu <em>d</em> orbitals. These findings are consistent with those reported by Hu <em>et al</em><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr1.jpg" height="425" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (286KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (286KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (aâ€“b) Top and side views of the crystal structure of a free-standing Cu<sub>2</sub><span><span>N monolayer. I, II, and III denote the possible adsorption sites. (c) 2D <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/brillouin-zone" title="Learn more about Brillouin zone from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Brillouin zone</a>. (d) Band structure, along with total and partial </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> of Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N monolayer.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">To examine the adsorption of a single Li/Na atom on monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N, we constructed a 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 supercell with possible adsorption sites I, II, and III as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> (a). Initially, the Li/Na atom is positioned 3.00&nbsp;Ã… above the sites I, II, and III to find the preferred adsorption site . Subsequently, these configurations are relaxed until the criteria for geometry optimization are satisfied. According to the computed adsorption energies (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> (a)), the lowest energy state for a single Li atom is at site II, with subsequent favorable sites being I and III. In contrast, the optimal binding site for a single Na atom is site I, followed by sites III and II. The strongest adsorption energy for Li is âˆ’1.80&nbsp;eV, and for Na, it is âˆ’1.70&nbsp;eV, which are deemed sufficient to avoid the formation of metallic dendrites and achieve the desired voltage<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. The corresponding DOS for single Li and Na adsorb monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(b)âˆ’(c), respectively. Clearly, the metallic characteristics of the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N persist after the adsorption of metal-ions, which is beneficial for its potential use as anode material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr2.jpg" height="375" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (268KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (268KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a) The calculated adsorption energies for single Li and Na on adsorption sites I, II, and III. (bâ€“c) The total <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> of single Li and Na adsorbed monolayer Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N, respectively, and (d) corresponding ELF plots. (eâ€“f) Charge density difference plots for Li and Na, respectively. The cyan and yellow areas show charge depletion and accumulation, respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">To determine the bonding nature between adsorbing Li/Na-ion and Cu<sub>2</sub>N, the electron localization function (ELF) is analyzed. The ELF values vary from 0 to 1, with 0 denoting electron delocalization, 0.5 denoting an electronâ€“gas state, and 1 denoting complete electron localization. The ELF plots, shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d, reveal the formation of an electron gas-like state on the surface of the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N. Neither Li nor Na displays any localized electron basins in binding with the surface that are connected with chemical bonds in ELF. Instead, there is strong repulsion between the metal atoms and the surface, with bands of zero ELF between the interacting atoms, which is typical for <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-bonding" title="Learn more about ionic binding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic binding</a>. The formation of strong but reversible ionic binding between Li/Na and Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a> is beneficial in avoiding Li/Na clustering and favorable diffusion rates of Li/Na on the Cu<sub>2</sub>N surface. Furthermore, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> (e) and (f) depict the charge density differences and amount of charge transfer between metal atoms and monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N. Clearly, the charge is depleted from the Li/Na atom and accumulates between Li/Na and the Cu<sub>2</sub>N sheet, as indicated by the cyan and yellow clouds in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(e) and (f). To confirm these findings, Bader charge analysis is conducted, which verifies a charge transfer of 0.91/0.49 e from Li/Na to the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">Next, a stepwise adsorption of metal ions is carried out to anticipate the maximum storage capacity of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N. To do that, we set two criteria: First, ensure that the Liâ€“Li/Naâ€“Na distance is larger than the bond length in Li<sub>2</sub>(2.67&nbsp;Ã…)/Na<sub>2</sub>(3.08&nbsp;Ã…)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a> in order to prevent metal clustering. Second, verify that the chemical potential of the Li and Na on the Cu<sub>2</sub>N anode is less than or equal to that of the Li/Na atom (Î¼<sub>Li/Na</sub>)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>. This needs<span class="display"><span id="e0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>By combining Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0025" name="be0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(5)</span></span></a> and Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0030" name="be0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(6)</span></span></a>, we get:<span class="display"><span id="e0035" class="formula"><span class="label">(7)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-24-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x2202;</mi><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Li</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;lt;</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>0</mn></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="11.321ex" height="4.509ex" viewBox="0 -1194.3 4874.1 1941.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.735ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g transform="translate(120,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="2799" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(765,615)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2202"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(401,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(522,-110)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-66"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-410)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2202"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(401,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(568,-132)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4C"></use><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69" x="681" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(680,0)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(930,0)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1374,0)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3317,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4373,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">âˆ‚</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">f</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">âˆ‚</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Li</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo is="true">&lt;</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-24"><math><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">âˆ‚</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">f</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">âˆ‚</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Li</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo is="true">&lt;</mo><mn is="true">0</mn></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>This demonstrates that a negative slope of the formation energy curve is necessary for the Li/Na loading process. Therefore, we continue to add one more Li/Na to all possible free positions to find the preferred adsorption site for it and take the configuration with the lowest energy and continue adding Li/Na until either all possible positions are filled or the <em>E<sub>f</sub></em> slope becomes positive. The Li/Na atoms are first loaded on the top side of Cu<sub>2</sub>N, then on the bottom side. Finally, the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N can accommodate a total of 18 Li/Na atoms, with nine at the top and nine at the bottom. Importantly, the <em>E<sub>f</sub></em> slope remains negative, showing the possibility for more Li/Na storage (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a) and (b)). Further, the shortest Liâ€“Li/Naâ€“Na distance on fully loaded monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N is around 3.65&nbsp;Ã…, which is sufficiently large to avoid Li/Na atom clustering. The storage capacity of Cu<sub>2</sub>N for both Li and Na is 379.88 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, exceeding the predicted storage capacity of graphite (372 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for Li and&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;35 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for Na)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr3.jpg" height="522" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (320KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (320KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (aâ€“b) The calculated formation energies and (câ€“d) OCVs as a function of concentration&nbsp;<em>x</em>&nbsp;for Li<sub>x</sub>Cu<sub>2</sub>N and Na<sub>x</sub>Cu<sub>2</sub>N, respectively. The inset figures give relative formation energies with increasing Li and Na concentrations, respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">We further calculate the relative formation energy (E<sub>r</sub>) to capture the voltage evolution of Li/Na concentration using the two endpoint structures that correspond to pure Cu<sub>2</sub>N and
