xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Li</mi><mo is="true">,</mo><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow><msub is="true"><mi is="true">x</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub></msub><mi is="true">C</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">u</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi is="true">N</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-28"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Li</mi><mo is="true">,</mo><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow><msub is="true"><mi is="true">x</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub></msub><mi is="true">C</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">u</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi is="true">N</mi></mrow></math></script></span> and <em>x<sub>2</sub></em> and <em>x<sub>1</sub></em> represent the two adjacent concentrations of adsorbed Li/Na ions on Cu<sub>2</sub>N. Four voltage plateaus are obtained for both Li and Na, with an average OCV of about 1.39&nbsp;V and 0.82&nbsp;V, respectively.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>Now, we look at the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carrier-mobility" title="Learn more about carrier mobility from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carrier mobility</a><span> and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusivity</a> of metal ions on the Cu</span></span><sub>2</sub>N monolayer. The CI-NEB method is employed to calculate the diffusion path of metal ions and their corresponding minimal energy profile (MEP) for a single Li/Na atom scattered on the surface of Cu<sub>2</sub>N. The top views of the scattering paths evaluated in this work, together with their corresponding energy profiles, are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>. For Li, Path 1 implies the diffusion of a Li atom from the most stable site (II), characterized by the highest <em>E<sub>ad</sub></em>, to the nearest (II) site in the <em>ab</em>-direction. On the other hand, in Path 2, the Li atom diffuses over the (I) site to reach the nearest stable (II) site, following the <em>a</em>-direction. Clearly, the Li atom prefers to diffuse via Path 2, with a calculated diffusion barrier of 0.1&nbsp;eV, while the diffusion barrier for Path 1 is 0.19&nbsp;eV. Similarly, in the case of Na, Path 1 implies the diffusion of a Na atom from the most stable site (I) to the nearest (I) site along the <em>ab</em>-direction, while Path 2 involves the Na atom diffusing to the nearest stable site (I) along the <em>a</em><span>-direction. The Na atom prefers diffusing through Path 1, with a calculated diffusion barrier of 0.01&nbsp;eV, while the diffusion barrier for Path 2 is 0.053&nbsp;eV. The variation in diffusion barriers along different directions is not available in many well-known <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/two-dimensional-materials" title="Learn more about 2D materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">2D materials</a> including graphene, MoS</span><sub>2</sub>, VS<sub>2</sub>, and Ti<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>. This uniaxial anisotropic movement of Li/Na significantly reduces the scattering effect, which is highly advantageous for LIBs/SIBs. Besides, our predicted Li barrier for Cu<sub>2</sub>N is significantly lower than that of graphene (0.32&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a> and other prominent commercial Li-anodes like TiO<sub>2</sub> (0.4â€“1.0&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a><span> and <a href="/topics/materials-science/silicon" title="Learn more about silicon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">silicon</a> (0.6â€“0.8&nbsp;eV)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a><span>. It is even less than the barriers predicted in several <a href="/topics/materials-science/two-dimensional-material" title="Learn more about 2D materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">2D materials</a> such as BC</span><sub>7</sub> (0.67&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>, MoS<sub>2</sub> (0.17&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, Ta<sub>2</sub>CS<sub>2</sub> (0.21&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>, holey graphyne (0.28&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, graphdiyne (0.7&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>, C<sub>3</sub>N/blue phosphorene (0.12&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>, VS<sub>2</sub>/blue phosphorene (0.16â€“0.17&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0315" name="bb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>, MoSSe (0.17&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0320" name="bb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>, and VS<sub>2</sub> (0.22&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, while being comparable with Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub> (0.068&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, V<sub>2</sub>C (0.045&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, aluminene (0.06&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, and phosphorene (0.08&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>. As for Na, its diffusion barrier is smaller than that of TiC (0.1&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, borophene (0.33&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, Ca<sub>2</sub>N (0.16&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, h-BAs (0.25&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0325" name="bb0325" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0325"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[65]</span></span></a>, Î²-Sb (0.1&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, borophane (0.09&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub> (0.1&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, NbS<sub>2</sub> (0.07)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, and comparable with Nb<sub>2</sub>C (0.02)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0330" name="bb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a>, V<sub>2</sub>N (0.01)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0335" name="bb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a>, and aluminene (0.03)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>. This suggests that monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N possesses high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ionic-mobility" title="Learn more about ionic mobility from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic mobility</a> and a rapid charge/discharge, both of which are desirable for an excellent anode material.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr4.jpg" height="446" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (333KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (333KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. Diffusion pathways and the corresponding energy profiles on the surface of the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N for (aâ€“b) Li and (câ€“d) Na.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">The structure distortion of anodes during the charging and discharging processes is one of the major causes of damage to metal-ion batteries. Recent studies have demonstrated that anode materials with self-healing ability can significantly improve the cycle life of metal-ion batteries. To evaluate the cyclic stability of the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N, we remove the metal ions and perform the <em>ai</em><span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-dynamics" title="Learn more about MD simulation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">MD simulation</a> on the remaining Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N sheet at 300&nbsp;K. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>, the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N swiftly restored its initial state within a mere 2.5&nbsp;ps, showing its favorable cyclic performance. Further, to identify the volume expansion of Cu<sub>2</sub>N during the lithiation and sodiation processes, a bilayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N structure with Li/Na atoms between the layers is used to estimate the distance change of the Cu<sub>2</sub>N bilayers after Li/Na intercalation, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>. Consequently, Li-intercalation causes a volume expansion of 4.14&nbsp;% (4.02&nbsp;Ã… after lithiation from 3.86&nbsp;Ã… for pristine Cu<sub>2</sub>N bilayer), which is significantly less than the 10&nbsp;% expansion predicted for graphite<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0340" name="bb0340" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0340"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[68]</span></span></a>. As for Na, it exhibits a volume expansion of 35.23&nbsp;% (5.22&nbsp;Ã…) owing to its larger size. However, this value is far smaller than the estimated 347&nbsp;% expansion of Na intercalated graphite along the <em>c</em>-axis<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0345" name="bb0345" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0345"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[69]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr5.jpg" height="403" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (772KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (772KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <em>ai</em><span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/molecular-dynamics" title="Learn more about MD simulations from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">MD simulations</a> of the monolayer Cu</span><sub>2</sub><span>N recovery process at 300&nbsp;K with fully removed (aâ€“e) Li and (fâ€“j) <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a>.</span></p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr6.jpg" height="261" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (141KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (141KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Schematic crystal structure of bilayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N (a) before and after charging (b) Li and (c) Na. The blue and green spheres represent Li and Na atoms, respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100"><span>Vacancy creation during electrode manufacture or with <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-vibration" title="Learn more about lattice vibrations from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice vibrations</a> at high temperatures is always a possibility</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. Therefore, examining the effect of vacancy formations on the electronic conductivity of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N is desirable. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>, we introduced single Cu and N-vacancy defects on the 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 supercell of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N. The formation energies for Cu and N vacancies are 5.43&nbsp;eV and 8.97&nbsp;eV, respectively. This demonstrates that Cu vacancies occur more readily than N vacancies in monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N. The computed vacancy formation energy values are comparable to those of graphene (7.7&nbsp;eV)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0350" name="bb0350" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0350"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[70]</span></span></a>, suggesting a strong bonding between Cuâ€“Cu and Cuâ€“N in Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N. Moreover, the N vacancy exhibits a nonmagnetic <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ground-state" title="Learn more about ground state from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ground state</a>, which is consistent with pristine Cu</span><sub>2</sub>N. Conversely, the Cu vacancy results in a magnetic moment of 2.07 ÂµB in the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub><span>N. The vacancy-induced <a href="/topics/materials-science/magnetism" title="Learn more about magnetism from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">magnetism</a> has also been observed in graphene.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr7.jpg" height="470" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (438KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (438KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. Relaxed configurations of the 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 Cu<sub>2</sub>N supercell with (a) single Cu and (b) N vacancies. The partial density of states for 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 Cu<sub>2</sub>N supercell with (c) Cu and (d) N vacancies. The black dotted hollow circles indicate the missing atom, and the light-brown filled circles show the possible sites tested for the adsorption of Li and Na atoms.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">Next, we examine the adsorption of Li-ion and Na-ion on the vacancy-defected 3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;1 supercell of Cu<sub>2</sub>N monolayer with four possible sites, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a> (a) and (b). As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0005" name="bt0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>, in the case of Cu vacancy, both Li and Na preferred to adsorb at the top of the vacancy site Cu<sub>Cu</sub> (<em>E<sub>ad</sub></em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;-3.33&nbsp;eV for Li and âˆ’3.34&nbsp;eV for Na). For N vacancy as well, Cu site V<sub>Cu</sub> (<em>E<sub>ad</sub></em><span>&nbsp;=&nbsp;-1.90&nbsp;eV for Li and âˆ’1.44&nbsp;eV for Na) is energetically more favorable. In contrast to graphene, here, the introduction of <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a><span> substantially enhances the Li/Na binding ability, indicating the positive effect of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> on the surface. To estimate the chargingâ€“discharging rate of vacancy-defected Cu</span></span><sub>2</sub>N, we calculate Li and Na diffusion barriers on the surface. In the Cu vacancy case, where Li/Na adsorption is favorable at the vacancy site, we calculate the diffusion of Li/Na between two adjacent equivalent sites with a Cu vacancy site positioned in the middle (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> (a) and (b)). The calculated migration barriers for Li and Na are 0.07 and 0.096&nbsp;eV, respectively. Notably, the migration barrier for Li is relatively low compared to pristine Cu<sub>2</sub>N, whereas the migration barrier for Na is comparable to pristine Cu<sub>2</sub>N. Similarly, in the N vacancy case, we consider the migration of Li/Na atoms from the stable site V<sub>Cu</sub> to the nearest V<sub>Cu</sub> site while passing over the N vacancy, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a> (c) and (d). The corresponding migration barriers for Li and Na are 0.23 and 0.09&nbsp;eV, respectively. These values are a bit higher than in pure Cu<sub>2</sub>N but still very low when compared with other 2D anode materials, demonstrating their suitability for metal-ion battery applications.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot rowsep-0 colsep-0" id="t0005"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0045"><p id="sp0060"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. Adsorption energies for Li and Na on Cu and N vacancy mediated monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N at different sites.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col" class="align-left" rowspan="2"><strong>Cu vacancy</strong></th><th scope="col" class="align-char" colspan="2"><strong><em>E<sub>ad</sub></em> (eV)</strong></th><th scope="col" class="align-char" rowspan="2"><strong>N vacancy</strong></th><th scope="col" class="align-left" colspan="2"><strong><em>E<sub>ad</sub></em> (eV)</strong></th></tr><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col" class="align-left"><strong>Li</strong></th><th scope="col" class="align-char"><strong>Na</strong></th><th scope="col" class="align-char"><strong>Li</strong></th><th scope="col" class="align-left"><strong>Na</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">V<sub>H</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.65</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.28</td><td class="align-left">V<sub>H</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.68</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.35</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">V<sub>Cu</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’3.33</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’3.34</td><td class="align-left">V<sub>Cu</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.91</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.44</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">V<sub>Cu-I</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.17</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.33</td><td class="align-left">V<sub>N</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.89</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.34</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">V<sub>N</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’2.01</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.44</td><td class="align-left">V<sub>N-I</sub></td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.73</td><td class="align-char">âˆ’1.33</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr8.jpg" height="444" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (327KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (327KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224001879-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0040"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. Diffusion pathways and the corresponding energy profiles of Li and Na on the surface of Cu and N defected structures of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N. Li diffusion on (a) Cu and (c) N defected structures. Na diffusion on (b) Cu and (d) N defected structures.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0020"><h2 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">We have investigated the potential of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N as an anode material for Li and Na-ion batteries using first-principles calculations. Our calculations show that the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N has a strong affinity for Li and Na atoms, with negative adsorption energies of around 1.80 and 1.43&nbsp;eV, respectively. The calculated storage capacity for both Li and Na is determined to be 379.88 mAh.g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Furthermore, the monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N exhibits ultra-low migration barriers of 0.10&nbsp;eV for Li and 0.01&nbsp;eV for Na, significantly surpassing the migration barriers found in commercial graphite and most of the known 2D materials. The insertion of Li and Na atoms into the interlayer space of Cu<sub>2</sub>N induces a slight swelling effect that results in volume expansion of 4.14 and 35.23&nbsp;%, respectively. Furthermore, the presence of vacancy defects enhanced the binding energies and decreased the Li diffusion barrier. This suggests that, in contrast to commercial anode materials such as graphene, vacancy defects are not hazardous to monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N for use in metal-ion batteries. These findings provide valuable insights for the experimental implementation of monolayer Cu<sub>2</sub>N as a potential anode material for metal-ion batteries.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><strong>Ali Sufyan:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Writing â€“ original draft, Visualization, Validation, Software, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Muhammad Sajjad:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Visualization. <strong>J. Andreas Larsson:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Visualization, Validation, Funding acquisition, Formal analysis.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">We thank Knut och Alice Wallenberg foundation, Sweden and Kempeâ€“stiftelserna, Sweden for financial support. The computations were enabled by resources provided by the Swedish National Infrastructure for Computing (SNIC) at HPC2N and NSC, partially funded by the <span id="gp005">Swedish Research Council</span> through grant agreement no. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2018-05973</span></span></a>.</div></section></div><div class="related-content-links u-display-none-from-md"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-small" type="button"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Recommended articles</span></span></button></div><div class="text-content u-font-serif"><section id="da005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Data availability</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Data will be made available on request.</div></section></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="bi005"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="bs005"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-bs005"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" id="ref-id-b0005" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0005"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">M.A. Hannan, S.B. href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Bending%20the%20Rules%3A%20Contrasting%20Vacancy%20Energetics%20and%20Migration%20in%20Graphite%20and%20Carbon%20Nanotubes&amp;publication_year=2006&amp;author=A.V.%20Krasheninnikov&amp;author=P.O.%20Lehtinen&amp;author=A.S.%20Foster&amp;author=R.M.%20Nieminen" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (3)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0301010425000655"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">First-principles insight into SnS&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;/graphene heterostructure as potential anode materials for rechargeable lithium/sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Chemical Physics</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0045">The investigation of anode materials possessing stable capacity, outstanding electrical conductivity, and rapid ion transport is crucial for the advancement of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Previous research has demonstrated that graphene-based heterostructures display outstanding electrical conductivity, high mechanical rigidity, and specific capacity when utilized as anodes. In this work, we systematically investigated the use of SnS<sub>2</sub>/graphene (SnS<sub>2</sub>/G) heterostructure as anode materials for LIBs and SIBs through first-principles calculations. The resultsindicate that, in comparison with the monolayer SnS<sub>2</sub>, the SnS<sub>2</sub>/G heterojunction demonstrates metallic characteristics and enhanced electrical conductivity. It also exhibits excellent Li and Na adsorption capacity, low ion migration barriers, and low open circuit voltage. The Na storage capacity of the SnS<sub>2</sub>/G heterojunction is 481.78 mAh/g, surpassing that of other common anodes. Moreover, the structure of Na embedding process remains stable, rendering it suitable for application as a high-performance anode material for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S146392622500038X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A green synthesis strategy for lithium/sodium-ion battery anodes: Morphology and structure engineering in biochar to boost comprehensive electrochemical performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Green Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom">Spherical biochar materials emerge as potential anode candidates for the forthcoming generation of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), attributed to their chemical stability and inherent safety. However, their industrial application is limited by poor electrochemical performance and pollution from the preparation process. Focusing on these issues, this work presents a green synthesis strategy that combines both morphological and structural engineering, utilizing ultrapure water as the sole reaction medium. Through successive hydrothermalâ€“carbonizationâ€“hydrothermal treatments, quasi-spherical biochar (CHCs-<em>T</em>) has been successfully synthesized. CHCs-900 exhibits a distinct and uniformly distributed quasi-spherical structure with a maximum carbon interlayer spacing (<em>d</em> = 4.11 Ã…) and the largest specific surface area (<em>S</em><sub>BET</sub> = 536.52 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). When utilized as an anode material for both LIBs and SIBs, CHCs-900 demonstrates excellent comprehensive electrochemical performance. Moreover, techniques such as electrochemical kinetics analysis and <em>ex situ</em> physicochemical characterization reveal that the quasi-spherical design of CHCs-900 facilitates efficient Na<sup>+</sup> transport and the enlarged carbon layer spacing reduces the diffusion energy barrier of Na<sup>+</sup>, while its large surface area and high porosity enhance charge transfer. This work underscores the importance of morphology and structure in advancing battery performance while minimizing environmental impact, aligning with global sustainability goals.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1386947724001954"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Two-dimensional Cu&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;Nâ€“A high-performance anode material for ion batteries with excellent electrical conductivity and electrolyte wettability</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Physica E: Low-Dimensional Systems and Nanostructures</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Additionally, the unique layered structure effectively mitigates material degradation caused by volume fluctuations during metal ion adsorption and desorption. Numerous studies have demonstrated that 2D anode materials possess high capacity, excellent rate performance, outstanding chemical stability, and good electrical conductivity, leading to impressive electrochemical performance [14â€“17]. Furthermore, 2D materials with nontrivial lattice structures can exhibit a variety of physical properties protected by lattice symmetry.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Determining suitable anode materials is crucial in the advancement of lithium-ion and sodium-ion battery technologies. We propose that the two-dimensional (2D) material Cu<sub>2</sub>N holds promise as a viable anode candidate. The Cu<sub>2</sub>N monolayer exhibits a stable checkerboard lattice crystal structure, ensuring structural integrity. Its excellent metallic electronic structure facilitates efficient conductivity during battery operation. We have observed that Li/Na ions can chemically bond to Cu<sub>2</sub>N substrates via specific charge exchange mechanisms. Moreover, the Cu<sub>2</sub>N monolayer demonstrates favorable wettability and compatibility with common electrolytes used in lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries, including solvent molecules and metal salts. Our findings indicate that the Li/Na storage capacity of the Cu<sub>2</sub>N monolayer reaches approximately 760/760 mAh/g, surpassing that of graphite anodes significantly. Notably, the Li/Na diffusion barrier on the Cu<sub>2</sub>N monolayer is merely 5/13&nbsp;meV, lower than that of most other 2D anode materials. Our results underscore the potential of the Cu<sub>2</sub>N monolayer as an outstanding electrode material, offering high storage capacity, rapid charge/discharge rates, and favorable wettability with electrolytes.</div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">Â© 2024 The Author(s). Published by Elsevier B.V.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related     pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
      <span id="pendo-answer-rating"></span>
      <script type="text/x-mathjax-config;executed=true">

          "fast-preview": {

          },

          PreviewHTML: { linebreaks: { automatic: true } },
          'HTML-CSS': { linebreaks: { automatic: true } },
          SVG: {
            scale: 90,
            linebreaks: { automatic: true }
          }
        });
      </script>
